definitions.definition: to move or make something move around a central point

examples.text: The wheels of the car began to turn.
I can't get the screw to turn.
The blades of the helicopter were turning slowly.
I turned the knob and pushed the door open.
He turned the key in the lock.
She turned the wheel sharply to the left.

definitions.definition: to move your body or part of your body so as to face or start moving in a different direction
definitions.sensetop: turn to do something+ adv./prep.turn something + adv./prep.turn something

examples.text: We turned and headed for home.
She turned to look at me.
He turned back to his work.
I turned away and looked out of the window.
He **turned his back** to the wall.
I **turned my face** to the sky.
She **turned her head** away.
I only turned my back for a second.
Lee turned to face her.
While his back was turned (= towards me) I sneaked a look at his notes.

definitions.definition: to move something so that it is in a different position or facing a different direction

examples.text: She turned the chair on its side to repair it.
Turn the sweater inside out before you wash it.

definitions.definition: to change the direction you are moving or travelling in; to make something change the direction it is moving in
definitions.sensetop: turn into something+ adv./prep.turn left/rightturn somethingturn something into somethingturn something + adv./prep.

examples.text: He turned into a narrow street.
We turned down a dark alleyway.
Turn left at the traffic lights.
The man **turned the corner** and disappeared.
I turned the car into the car park.
The pilot attempted to turn the aircraft towards a wooded area.

definitions.definition: to bend or curve in a particular direction

examples.text: The road turns to the left after the church.
After a while the path turns sharply right.
The river turns north at this point.

definitions.definition: if you turn a page of a book or magazine, you move it so that you can read the next page

examples.text: He sat turning the pages idly.
Turn to p.23.

definitions.definition: to change into a particular state or condition; to make something do this

examples.text: The leaves were turning brown.
They say her hair turned white overnight.
I could feel my face **turn red** with embarrassment.
The weather has turned cold.
He turned nasty when we refused to give him the money.
He decided to **turn professional**.
The heat turned the milk sour.
She turned a deathly shade of white when she heard the news.
He's a lawyer turned politician *(= he used to be a lawyer but is now a politician)*.

definitions.definition: to aim or point something in a particular direction
definitions.sensetop: turn something on somebody/something/yourselfturn something to somebody/something/yourselfturn to somebody/something/yourself

examples.text: Police turned water cannon on the rioters.
He turned the gun on himself.
She looked at him then turned her attention back to me.
His thoughts turned to his dead wife.
Don't turn your anger on the children.
Many supporters are now turning their criticism on the manager.
He tried to forget the events of past few days and turned his thoughts to practical tasks.

definitions.definition: to start to come in or go out

examples.text: The tide is turning—we'd better get back.

definitions.definition: to make or let somebody/something go into a particular place or state

examples.text: They turned the horse into the field.
to turn the dogs loose

definitions.definition: to fold something in a particular way

examples.text: She turned down the blankets and climbed into bed.
He turned up the collar of his coat and hurried out into the rain.

definitions.definition: to perform a movement by moving your body in a circle

examples.text: to turn cartwheels/somersaults

definitions.definition: if a game turns or somebody turns it, it changes the way it is developing so that a different person or team starts to win
to reach or pass a particular age or time

examples.text: She turns 21 in June.
It's turned midnight.

definitions.definition: when your stomach turns or something turns your stomach, you feel as though you will vomit
to shape something on a lathe

examples.text: to turn a chair leg
turned boxes and bowls

definitions.definition: as was shown or proved by later events

examples.text: I didn't need my umbrella, as it turned out *(= because it didn't rain)*.

definitions.definition: to be well, badly, etc. dressed
likely to be very shocked or angry

examples.text: My father would turn in his grave if he knew.

definitions.definition: used to report what somebody says or does, when this is surprising or annoying

examples.text: How could she turn round and say that, after all I've done for her?

wordOrigin: Old English tyrnan, turnian (verb), from Latin tornare, from tornus ‘lathe’, from Greek tornos ‘lathe, circular movement’; probably reinforced in Middle English by Old French turner. The noun (Middle English) is partly from Anglo-Norman French tourn, partly from the verb.
